title: 111_hr3923
content: The Act is titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" and includes definitions. The Act defines the "District" as the Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District of Boulder, Colorado, and "Federal land" as specific parcels in the National Forest. The Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District of Boulder, Colorado is proposing a land exchange with the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado. The non-Federal land involved is approximately 5.17 acres in unincorporated Boulder County. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The map numbered 3 shows the area for the proposed exchange, dated November 12, 2009. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District in Boulder County, Colorado is proposing a land exchange with the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests. If the District offers to convey its non-Federal land to the Secretary and the offer is accepted, the Secretary will convey Federal land to the District. This exchange is subject to the provisions of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District in Boulder County, Colorado is proposing a land exchange with the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests. The exchange is subject to Section 206 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, with some modifications. The Secretary may accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the Federal land value. The District must cover costs for land surveys, appraisals, and other administrative expenses as part of the exchange agreement. The land exchange between the Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District and the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests must allocate administrative costs and be completed within 1 year. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights and any additional terms required by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to conduct the sale of Federal land. The Secretary may offer to sell Federal land to the District for fair market value if the land exchange is not completed within 1 year of the Act's enactment. Proceeds from the sale shall be deposited in a fund. The Secretary shall deposit proceeds from any cash equalization payment or sale of Federal land in the fund established under the Sisk Act. These funds can be used by the Secretary for acquiring land or interests in the National Forest without further appropriation. The Secretary can use funds from the Sisk Act for acquiring land in the National Forest without further appropriation. Non-Federal land acquired will be added to the National Forest and managed according to relevant laws and regulations. Revocation of public orders withdrawing Federal land from entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws is necessary for conveyance to the District. Federal land not already withdrawn or segregated under various laws will be conveyed to the District. The Federal land is withdrawn until the conveyance to the District under public land laws and the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970.
